elements • Value to find Output • Index of element • Or; No such Element 1.1 Linear Search Pro • Elements don’t have to be sorted Con • Slow runtime Runtime O(n) Algorithm 1 LinearSearch(A, b) 1: for i = 1, . . . , n do 2: if A[i] = b then 3: return i 4: end if 5: end for 6: return Not Found 1.2 Binary Search Pro • Fast runtime Con • Elements have to be sorted Runtime O(log n) Algorithm 2 BinarySearch(A, b) 1: l ← 0, r ← n 2: while l ≤ r do 3: m ← l + ⌊ r−l 2 ⌋ 4: if A[m] = b then 5: return m 6: end if 7: if b < A[m] then 8: l ← m − 1 9: else 10: r ← m + 1 11: end if 12: end while 1 2 Sorting Algorithms Input • Array of elements Output • Sorted Array (A[1] ≤ A[2] ≤ · · · ≤ A[n]) 2.1 Bubble Sort Pro • Easy implemented Con • Horrible runtime, never actually use this. Runtime O(n2) Algorithm 3 BubbleSort(A) 1: for i = 1, . . . , n do 2: for j = 1, . . . , n − 1 do 3: if A[j] > A[j + 1] then 4: switch A[j] and A[j + 1] 5: end if 6: end for 7: end for 2.2 Selection Sort Pro • Easy implemented • Less switching of elements then Bubble Sort (only O(n)) Con • Still horrible runtime Runtime O(n2) Algorithm 4 SelectionSort(A) 1: for j = 1, . . . , n do 2: k ← 0 3: for i = 1, . . . , j do ▷ assigns the maximum value in A[1, . . . , j] to k 4: if A[i] > A[k] then 5: k ← i 6: end if 7: end forswitch A[k] and A[n − j + 1] 8: end for 2.3 InsertionSort Pro • Easy implemented • Less comparissons then Bubble Sort (only O(n log n)) Con 2 • Still horrible runtime Runtime O(n2) Algorithm 5 InsertionSort(A) 1: for j = 2, . . . , n do 2: find position k of A[j] in A[1, . . . , j − 1] 3: insert A[j] at A[k] and move A[k, . . . , j − 1] to A[k + 1, . . . , j] 4: end for 2.4 Merge Sort Pro • Good Runtime Con • Complicated to implement (especially ecause you need to implement the merge) Runtime O(n log n) Algorithm 6 Merge(A, l, m, r) 1: B ← [1, . . . , r − l + 1] 2: i ← l 3: j ← m + 1 4: k ← 1 5: while i ≤ m ∧ j ≤ r do 6: if A[i] < A[j] then 7: B[k] ← A[i] 8: i ← i + 1, k ← k + 1 9: else 10: B[k] ← A[j] 11: j ← j + 1, k ← k + 1 12: end if 13: end while 14: while i ≤ m do 15: B[k] ← A[i] 16: i ← i + 1, k ← k + 1 17: end while 18: while j ≤ r do 19: B[k] ← A[j] 20: j ← j + 1, k ← k + 1 21: end while 22: copy B to A[l, . . . , r] Algorithm 7 MergeSort(A, l = 0, r = n) 1: if f < r then 2: m ← l + ⌊ r−l 2 ⌋ 3: MergeSort(A,l,m) 4: MergeSort(A,m+1,r) 5: Merge(A,l,m,r) 6: end if 3 2.5 Quick Sort Pro • Runtime almost as good,of a runtime as merge sort, but less space complexity. Con • Not easy to implement • Can take O(n2) Runtime O(n2) (worst-case) O(n log n) (most cases) Algorithm 8 QuickSort(A, l, r) 1: if l < r then 2: k ← Split(A, l, r) 3: QuickSort(A,l,k-1) 4: QuickSort(A,k+1,r) 5: end if Algorithm 9 Split(A, l, r) 1: i ← l, j ← r − 1, p ← A[r] 2: repeat 3: while i < r ∧ A[i] ≤ p do 4: i ← i + 1 5: end while 6: while j ≥ l ∧ A[i] > p do 7: j ← j + 1 8: end while 9: if i < j then 10: switch A[i] and A[j] 11: end if 12: until i > j 13: switch A[i] and A[j] 2.6 Heap Sort Pro • Good Runtime Con • Requires extra datastructure and space, refere to section 3.5.1 • Bad Locality Runtime O(n log n) Algorithm 10 HeapSort(A) 1: H ← make-heap(A) 2: for i = 1, . . . , n do 3: A[i] ← extract-min(H) 4: end for 4 3 Datastructures and Abstract Data Types (ADTs) the element v to the stack. pop() removes the element on top of the stack (the one added the most recent). 3.4.2 Implementation comparisson (Doubly)LinkedList push(v) O(1) pop() O(1) 3.5 Sorted Datastructures If we regularly want to search in a mutable set of data, we may want to store it in a way that we can easily search through it. In this section we disscuss such datastructures. 3.5.1 Binary Tree/Heap A binary tree is a tree where every node has two children, except the ones in the last two rows. The last row fills from left to right. Always has the element that satisfies the heap condition the best on the top. After every change the heap condition has to be restored with the following algorithm. Algorithm 11 make-heap(A) 1: for k = ⌊ A.length 2 ⌋, . . . , 1 do 2: heapify(A, k) 3: end for Algorithm 12 extract(-min)(H) 1: res← H[0] 2: H[0] ← H[H.length] 3: H.length ← H.length − 1 4: return res 6 Algorithm 13 (min-)heapify(A, s) 1: left ← 2s 2: right ← 2s + 1 3: if left ≤ A.length ∧ A[left] < A[s] then 4: smallest← lef t 5: else 6: smallest← s 7: end if 8: if right ≤ A.length ∧ A[right] < A[smallest] then 9: smallest ← right 10: end if 11: if smallest̸=s then 12: swap(A[s], A[smallest]) 13: heapify(A, smallest) 14: end if 3.5.2 AVL Tree A AVL tree is a datastructure where searching for a element is possible in O(log n). The tree has a balance factor |hl − hr| and if it’s absolute value gets bigger then 1 at A, depending on where the imbalance at came from we do one of the following rotations (C is the vertex from where the imbalance came from). You have to apply this process from the bottom up for it to work. Right Rotation A B C A B C Left Rotation A B C A B C Left-Right Rotation A B C C AB Right-Left Rotation A B C A B C 3.6 Union Find Algorithm 14 make(V ) 1: rep[v] ← v ∀ ∈ V Algorithm 15 same(u, v) 1: return rep[u] = rep[v] 7 Algorithm 16 union(u, v) 1: for x ∈ members[rep[u]] do 2: rep[x] ← rep[v] 3: members[rep[v]] ← members[rep[v]] ∪ {x} 4: end for 4 Dynamic Programming An approach to problem solving by spliting the problem into smaller subproblems that can be solved recursivly. Often this recursion gets represented as a table of dimension of the recursion inputs. The dimensions often can be read of the runtime unless one iteration has a non constant runtime. 8 5 Graphs Graph Theory is an abstraction layer to a lot of very common problems in computer science. By abstracting these problems to graphs we can apply lots of graph algorithms to easily solve these problems. A graph can be used to represent networks, relations, etc. 5.1 Terms and Definitions Term Description Mathematical Definition Graph G a Graph is a set of vertices and a set of edges. G = (V, E) Edge e a edge e connects two vertices u and v. e = {u, v} u adjacent2 to v there exists an edge between u and v. {u, v} ∈ E e incident to v e is a edge between v and any other vertex. ∃u where e = {u, v} ∈ E Degree of v the amount of incident edges to v. deg(v) = |{e ∈ E|∃u, e = u, v}| Walk W a sequence W of directly adjacent vertices of length l. W = (v0, . . . , vl) Path P walk P with length l and no repeat- ing vertices. P = (v0, . . . , vl) where ∀i, j 0 ≤ i, j ≤ l, vi ̸= vi Closed Walk Z a walk Z with length l and the first and the last vertices being the same. Z = (v0, . . . , vl) where v0 = vl Cycle C a walk C with length l and none ex- cept for the first and the last vertices not being the same. C = (v0, . . . , vl) where ∀i, j 0 < i, j < l, vi ̸= vj and v0 = vl v reachable3 from u there exists a walk from u to v (equivalence relation) ∃C where C = (u, . . . , v) connected component equivalence class of reachable. connected graph if there exists only one connected component in a graph. ∀u, v ∈ V, v reachable form u Euler walk a walk which contains every edge ex- actly once. Hamilton path a path which contains every vertex exactly once. Euler circuit4 a closed walk which contains every edge exactly once. 2sometimes directly adjacent, since there also exists indirectly adjacent 3sometimes indirectly adjacent to instead of reachable from 4sometimes also called euler cycle or euler tour 9 5.2 EulerTour Algorithm Finds a Euler tour Runtime O(m) Algorithm 17 EulerTour(G) 1: Z ← empty list 2: for each v ∈ V , unmarked do 3: EulerWalk(G, Z, v) 4: end for 5: return Z Algorithm 18 EulerWalk(G, Z, u) 1: for {u, v} ∈ E unmarked do 2: mark {u, v} 3: EulerWalk(G, Z, v) 4: end for 5.3 Directed Graph; Terms and Definitions Term Description Mathematical Definition Directed Graph Same as a undirected graph, except for edges, now they have a direction. G = (V, E) (directed) Edge e a edge from vertex u to vertex v. e = (u, v) v successor to u there is an edge from u to v. (u, v) ∈ E u predeccessor to v there is an edge from u to v. (u, v) ∈ E in-degree of v the number of edges to v. degin(v) = |{u ∈ V |(u, v) ∈ E}| out-degree of u the number of edges from u. degout(u) = |{v ∈ V |(u, v) ∈ E}| source u a vertex with no edges to itself. degin = 0 sink v a vertex with no edges from itself. degout = 0 5.4 Depth-First-Search (DFS) Goes through all the vertices, while first going as deep as possible and then exploring other options. Runtime O(n + m) with adjacency-lists, O(n2) with adjacency-matrices Algorithm 19 DFS(G) 1: for u ∈ V , unmarked do 2: visit(u) 3: end for Algorithm 20 visit(G, u) 1: mark u 2: for {u, v} ∈ E, where v unmarked do 3: visit(G, v) 4: end for 10 5.5 Breadth-First-Search Goes through all the vertices, while first exploring all options one level deep, then doing the same on the next level of deepness. Runtime O(n + m) with adjacency-lists, O(n2) with adjacency-matrices Algorithm 21 BFS(G, s) 1: Q ← {s} 2: while Q ̸= ∅ do 3: u ← dequeue(Q) 4: for (u, v) ∈ E, where v unmarked do 5: mark v 6: enqueue(Q, v) 7: end for 8: end while 5.6 Shortest Path Algorithms 5.6.1 Dijkstra Finds the shortest path from vertex s to all other vertices on a graph without negative weighted edges. Runtime O((m + n) · log n) Algorithm 22 Dijkstra(G, s) 1: d[s] ← 0; d[v] ← ∞ ∀v ∈ V \{s} 2: H ← make-heap(V ); decrease-key(H, s, 0) 3: while V not empty do 4: u ← extract-min(H) 5: mark u 6: for (u, v) ∈ E, v unmarked do 7: d[v] ← min{d[v], d[u] + c(u, v)} 8: decrease-key(H, v, d[v]) 9: end for 10: end while 5.6.2 Bellman-Ford Finds the shortest path from vertex s to all other vertices on a graph with non-negative and negative weighted edges. Algorithm 23 Bellman-Ford(G, s) 1: d[s] ← 0; d[v] ← ∞ ∀v ∈ V \{s} 2: for i ∈ {1, . . . , n − 1} do 3: for (u, v) ∈ E do 4: d[v] ← min{d[v], d[u] + c(u, v)} 5: end for 6: end for 11 5.7 MST Algorithms 5.7.1 Boruvka Runtime O((m + m) · log n) Algorithm 24 Boruvka(G) 1: F ← ∅ 2: while F not a spanning tree do 3: (S1, . . . , Sk) ← connected components in the graph G′ = (V, F ) 4: (e1, . . . , ek) ← minimal edges on S1, . . . , Sk 5: F ← F ∪ {e1, . . . , ek} 6: end while 5.7.2 Prim Runtime O((m + n) · log n) Algorithm 25 Prim(G, s) 1: H ← make-heap(V, ∞) 2: d[s] ← 0; d[v] ← ∞∀v ∈ V \{s} 3: decrease-key(H, s, 0) 4: while H ̸= ∅ do 5: u ← extract-min(H) 6: mark u 7: for {u, v} ∈ E, v unmarked do 8: d[v] ← min{d[v], c(u, v)} 9: decrease-key(H, v, d[v]) 10: end for 11: end while 5.7.3 Kruskal Runtime O(m · log m + n · log n) Algorithm 26 Kruskal(G) 1: F ← ∅ 2: U F ← make-union-find(V ) 3: sort(E) 4: for {u, v} ∈ E do 5: if ¬same(u, v) then 6: F ← F ∪ {{u, v}} 7: union(u, v) 8: end if 9: end for 12 5.8 All to all shortest path Algorithms 5.8.1 Floyd-Warshall Algorithm Runtime O(n3) Algorithm 27 Floyd-Warshall(G) 1: for u ∈ V do 2: d0 uu ← 0 3: for v ∈ V \{u} do 4: if (u, v) ∈ E then 5: d0 uv ← c(u, v) 6: else 7: d0 uv ← ∞ 8: end if 9: end for 10: end for 11: for i = 1, . . . , n do 12: for u ∈ V do 13: for v ∈ V do 14: di uv ← min{di−1 uv , d i−1 ui + d i−1 iv } 15: end for 16: end for 17: end for 18: return dn 5.8.2 Johnson’s Algorithm Runtime O(n · (m + n) · log n) Algorithm 28 Johnson(G) 1: G′ = (V ′, E′) where V ′ ← V ∪ {z}, E′ ← E ∪ {{z, v0}, . . . , {z, vn}} 2: h ← Bellman-Ford(G′, z) 3: ˆc(u, v) ← c(u, v) + h(u) − h(v) 4: d[v] ← Dijkstra(G with the cost function ˆc, s) ∀v ∈ V 5: return d 13
